      $. y Sparse
Rank_Infinity -- operates on x and y as a whole -- WHY_IS_THIS_IMPORTANT?


Gives a noun that can replace (numeric) y in working code, with only the non-zero atoms of $.y stored in memory. See the entry_in_the_J_Dictionary for details
When $.y is displayed in the J session, only its non-zero atoms are shown, together with their indexes.
   $ y=: 0 0 1 0 2.5 0 0 999 _ 0 0 0
12
   ] z=: $.y
2 |   1
4 | 2.5
7 | 999
8 |   _
   $ z
12

**** Common uses ****
To save storage when storing a sparse array.

      x $. y Sparse
Rank_Infinity -- operates on x and y as a whole -- WHY_IS_THIS_IMPORTANT?


n&$. is a collection of functions for creating and handling sparse_arrays and converting them to/from ordinary arrays.
The noun n can take one of the values 0 1 2 3 4 5 7 8 or their negations. See the entry_in_the_J_Dictionary for details of the actual function specified by n plus the form of the y-argument it expects.

Chapter 30 of 'Learning J' by Roger Stokes (also accessible via 'LJ' from the J Help pages) gently introduces to Sparse Arrays, going through various examples.
